  "article_text": [
    "we work over an algebraically closed field @xmath6 of characteristic zero . throughout",
    ", @xmath0 is a connected affine algebraic group with lie algebra @xmath1 .",
    "suppose for a while that @xmath0 is semisimple . in 1979",
    ", jacques dixmier proved a nice theorem on vector fields on @xmath1 .",
    "specifically , he showed that any vector field annihilating all @xmath0-invariant polynomials on @xmath1 lies in the @xmath2$]-module generated by the `` adjoint vector fields '' ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem2.1 ) .",
    "a substantial generalisation of dixmier s theorem was found by levasseur and stafford @xcite .",
    "they explicitly described the centraliser of @xmath2^g$ ] in the algebra of differential operators on @xmath1 . on the level of vector fields",
    ", their result reduces to dixmier s theorem .",
    "the purpose of this paper is to explore similar problems in the general context of affine algebraic groups and their rational representations .",
    "we show that dixmier s argument applies to the coadjoint representations of the so - called 3-wonderful lie algebras .",
    "furthermore , the coadjoint representation can be replaced with an arbitrary ( finite - dimensional ) representation , and this leads to three types of interesting problems .",
    "let now @xmath0 be an arbitrary connected group .",
    "we say that @xmath1 is _ 3-wonderful _ if : ( i )  @xmath7 , ( ii )  @xmath8^g$ ] is a polynomial algebra of krull dimension @xmath9 , and ( iii )  the sum of degrees of free homogeneous generators of @xmath8^g$ ] equals @xmath10 .",
    "( here @xmath11 is the union of @xmath0-orbits of maximal dimension in @xmath12 . )",
    "this definition intends to axiomatise good properties of reductive lie algebras .",
    "there is also a method for generating new 3-wonderful algebras : if @xmath1 is @xmath13-wonderful and @xmath14 , then the semi - direct product @xmath15 has the same properties .",
    "below is a dixmier - type result for the coadjoint representation of a 3-wonderful lie algebra @xmath1 .",
    "[ thm:0.1 ] let @xmath16 be a polynomial vector field on @xmath12 .",
    "assume that @xmath16 annihilates all of @xmath8^g$ ] .",
    "then there is a polynomial mapping @xmath17 such that @xmath18 for any @xmath19 .    the proof is essentially based on the fact that @xmath7 and certain vector bundle on @xmath11 appears to be trivial .",
    "a posteriori , this is related to some good properties of a homomorphism of @xmath8$]-modules .",
    "let @xmath20 denote the set of all polynomial morphisms @xmath21 , where @xmath22 and @xmath23 are @xmath6-vector spaces .",
    "it is a free graded @xmath24$]-module of rank @xmath25 .",
    "consider the homomorphism @xmath26 , @xmath27 for @xmath19 .",
    "then theorem  [ thm:0.1 ] merely says that @xmath28 equals the submodule of vector fields annihilating all of @xmath8^g$ ] .",
    "furthermore , in the `` 3-wonderful case '' the kernel of @xmath29 appears to be a free @xmath8$]-module generated by @xmath0-equivariant morphisms .    for an arbitrary @xmath0-module @xmath22 , where @xmath1 is not necessarily @xmath13-wonderful",
    ", one can write up _ three _ similar homomorphisms and consider similar problems .",
    "the most obvious possibility is to replace @xmath12 with @xmath22 .",
    "this yields the homomorphism of @xmath24$]-modules @xmath30 .",
    "clearly , any vector field @xmath31 annihilates all of @xmath24^g$ ] .",
    "the problem on the opposite inclusion is related to the structure of @xmath32 , @xmath24^g$ ] , and @xmath33 , and we provide an appropriate analogue of theorem  [ thm:0.1 ] .",
    "two other possibilities are @xmath34 where we also describe the respective images under similar conditions , and give some illustrations .",
    "generalising the approach of @xcite , we regard the problem on @xmath28 as a special case of a problem on differential operators on @xmath22 .",
    "let @xmath35 denote the ring of differential operators on @xmath22 with polynomial coefficients .",
    "as @xmath24 $ ] is identified with the differential operators of order zero , one can consider the centraliser of @xmath24^g$ ] in @xmath35 , @xmath36^g)$ ] .",
    "each @xmath37 gives rise to a linear operator on @xmath22 and therefore a vector field . in this way",
    ", one obtains the lie algebra homomorphism @xmath38 the elements of @xmath39 are called the _ adjoint vector fields _ ( on @xmath22 ) . by the definition of @xmath29 , @xmath28 is the @xmath24$]-module generated by @xmath39 .",
    "clearly , @xmath40^g)$ ] contains @xmath24 $ ] and @xmath39 , and one may ask whether the subalgebra generated by @xmath24 $ ] and @xmath39 , denoted @xmath41 , is equal to @xmath42 . on the level of vector fields , the equality @xmath43 reduces to the assertion that any @xmath16 annihilating all of @xmath24^g$ ] lies in @xmath28 , i.e. , in @xmath24\\boldsymbol{\\varsigma}({{\\mathfrak g}})$ ] .    for the adjoint representation of a semisimple lie algebra , the equality @xmath43 is proved in @xcite . adapting that method",
    ", we obtain a sufficient condition for @xmath43 in a more general framework .",
    "we assume that @xmath24^g$ ] is a polynomial algebra and @xmath32 is a free @xmath24$]-module , and impose determinantal constraints on the embedding @xmath44",
    ". however , the reductivity of @xmath0 is not assumed .",
    "( see theorem  [ thm : main4 - 2 ] for precise formulations ) . the equality @xmath43 and other results on @xmath42 stem from assertions about certain @xmath0-stable subvariety of @xmath45 .",
    "recall that for any @xmath0-module @xmath22 , there is the moment map @xmath46 .",
    "then @xmath47 is defined by letting @xmath48 .",
    "consider also the @xmath24$]-module @xmath49 and its symmetric algebra , @xmath50}(e)$ ] .",
    "under appropriate constraints ( alluded to above ) , we prove that    * @xmath50}(e)$ ] is a factorial domain of krull dimension @xmath51 ; * @xmath52}(e))$ ] and it is also a complete intersection in @xmath45 ; * the generators of the ideal of @xmath53 are determined by a basis of @xmath32 .    from this , we deduce that @xmath54}(e)$ ] , where @xmath55 is the associated graded ring with respect to the filtration by the order of differential operators .",
    "then the equality @xmath43 follows .",
    "we also give a sufficient condition for @xmath42 to be a free @xmath24^g$]-module ( see theorem  [ thm : c_is_free ] ) .",
    "let @xmath56 be a @xmath57-graded semisimple lie algebra .",
    "this grading ( or the symmetric pair @xmath58 ) is said to be @xmath59-_regular _ , if @xmath60 contains a regular nilpotent element of @xmath1 .",
    "our main application concerns the isotropy representation @xmath61 .",
    "we show that the hypotheses of theorems  [ thm : main4 - 2 ] and [ thm : c_is_free ] are satisfied , modulo one exception , for @xmath61 if @xmath58 is @xmath59-regular .",
    "hence @xmath43 and @xmath42 is a free @xmath62^{g_0}$]-module in these cases .",
    "verification of all necessary conditions requires a detailed information on the structure of the null - cone in the @xmath63-module @xmath60 .",
    "we also provide other examples of the `` @xmath43 phenomenon '' ; in particular , those for the coadjoint representation of non - reductive lie algebras .",
    "the plan of the article is as follows .",
    "section  [ prelim ] contains preliminaries on group actions and differential operators . in section  [",
    "sect : kost ] , we prove our analogue of dixmier s result for the coadjoint representation of a @xmath13-wonderful lie algebra",
    ". then we discuss , in section  [ sect : mod ] , three generalisations to the case in which @xmath12 is replaced with an arbitrary @xmath0-module .",
    "section  [ sect : diff_op ] contains our results on the image of @xmath64 , @xmath50}(e)$ ] , and the equality @xmath43 . in section",
    "[ sect : z2 ] , we consider applications to @xmath57-gradings of semisimple lie algebras and provide some other examples .",
    "in section  [ sect : some_spec ] , we discuss possible connections between our results for @xmath57-gradings and another generalisation of dixmier s result obtained in @xcite .    _ some notation .",

    "* theorem8.6 ) .",
    "the above equality @xmath267 ( with @xmath271 semisimple ) means that each nonzero weight of @xmath22 ( with respect to @xmath272 ) is a multiple of a root . using this observation ,",
    "one easily obtains the complete list of irreducible representations of simple lie algebras satisfying assumption @xmath266 .",

    "another reason is that similar properties of sequences ( b ) and ( c ) for representations of reductive groups have been studied in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section8 ) .",
    "in section  [ sect : mod ] , three possibilities to generalise dixmier s results have been discussed .",
    "these are related to three sequences of modules over polynomial rings .",
    "it seems that case  ( a ) is the most interesting one , because the problem can further be transferred to the setting of differential operators on @xmath22 .",

    "[ prop : loc_free ] , many representations with trivial generic stabiliser will work .",
    "so , we concentrate on examples with non - trivial stabiliser , i.e. , with @xmath574 .    [ ex : theta3 ] take @xmath575 and @xmath576 , where @xmath577 is the @xmath578-th fundamental weight .",

    "[ ex : takif - f2 ] we describe non - reductive lie algebras whose coadjoint representation satisfies the hypotheses of theorem  [ thm : main4 - 2 ] .",
    "this yields an incarnation of the `` @xmath43 phenomenon '' in the non - reductive case .",
    "we detect such examples among @xmath13-wonderful algebras . by a previous discussion ( remarks  [ rmk:3wond - conn ] and [ essence ] ) , hypotheses 13 are always satisfied for them .",
    "thus , it remains only to have condition @xmath311 for @xmath28 .",
    "our examples exploit the semi - direct product construction ( see example  [ ex : new_wonder ] ) .",

    "there are two different generalisations of dixmier s result on adjoint vector fields in the context of the adjoint representation of semisimple lie algebras .    one possibility is provided by the levasseur - stafford description of @xmath609^g)$ ] ( * ? ?",
    "* theorem1.1 ) , see discussion in section  [ sect : diff_op ] . on the other hand ,",
    "the formulation given in remark  [ istolkov ] suggests the following question , which was raised by dixmier himself @xcite .",
    "the affirmative answer is obtained by levasseur and stafford @xcite .",
    "they proved that @xmath614^g\\}\\ ] ] is the left ideal of @xmath615 generated by @xmath39 .",
    "then a similar result was obtained for the isotropy representation of some symmetric pairs @xcite . to state that result , we need some preparations .",

    "+ is it true that one of them implies another ( under appropriate constraints ) ?",
    "at least , is there a relationship in case of isotropy representations of symmetric pairs ?",
    "the only `` bad '' @xmath59-regular symmetric pair @xmath503 is also distinguished by a bad behaviour of the commuting variety .",
    "recall that the commuting variety is @xmath625=0\\}$ ] , and it is irreducible for all @xmath59-regular pairs but that one . in the maximal rank case , the irreducibility is proved in @xcite .",

    "the weyl group of a graded lie algebra , _ math .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> let @xmath0 be a semisimple algebraic group with lie algebra @xmath1 . in 1979 , j.  dixmier proved that any vector field annihilating all @xmath0-invariant polynomials on @xmath1 lies in the @xmath2$]-module generated by the `` adjoint vector fields '' , i.e. , vector fields @xmath3 of the form @xmath4 $ ] , @xmath5 . </S>",
    "<S> a substantial generalisation of dixmier s theorem was found by levasseur and stafford . </S>",
    "<S> they explicitly described the centraliser of @xmath2^g$ ] in the algebra of differential operators on @xmath1 . on the level of vector fields , </S>",
    "<S> their result reduces to dixmier s theorem . </S>",
    "<S> the purpose of this paper is to explore similar problems in the general context of affine algebraic groups and their rational representations .    </S>"
  ]
}
